p: Sulfated polysaccharides (SPS) from micro- and macro-algae are the most studied bioactive group of carbohydrates with anti-inflammatory activity [ 255]. These compounds can vary widely in their composition, i.e., types of monosaccharides, and their degree of sulfation. Several microalgal genera have been explored for their anti-inflammatory properties, including Porphyridium (Rhodophyta), Phaeodactylum (Heterokonts), and Chlorella (Chlorophyta). Guzman et al. [ 108] reported that crude polysaccharide extracts from Chlorella stigmatophora and Phaeodactylum tricornutum demonstrated an anti-inflammatory response in a paw edema test. Of note, SPS from P. tricornutum showed a direct stimulatory effect on the immune cells as shown with in vitro and in vivo assays. Similarly, Matsui et al. [ 256] found that SPS from Porphyridium inhibited the migration of leukocytes to the sites of inflammation in vitro, and inhibited the development of erythema in vivo.
